author: Aditi R
text:
Meenakshi was fast asleep along with her two kids, when she was woken up by a loud thud around 2 a.m on Thursday.

When she opened the door, she realised that a part of her house had caved in.

As many as 22 other families living at Visalakshithottam near Mandavelli railway station, also heard the earth-shattering noise, which was the result of a part of the bridge adjoining the street, collapsing.

“It was very scary. What if it had been severe?” she asked pointing out to the big crack near her door that had been caused by the impact of the collapse.

Three houses had been constructed on the bridge; luckily, as residents put it, the owner of the house at the farthest end was away.

“We have told them several times not to live there, as it is an old bridge. We have also asked them to move to a better place, but they are reluctant,” said a Greater Chennai Corporation official who had come for inspection.

Residents, however, say they will move only if they are provided with an alternative place to which they can relocate.

They further claim that they are still waiting for an alternative housing facility, which officials had promised them last year.

Many residents have now temporarily moved out to the streets to avoid any mishap.
title: Partial collapse of bridge triggers panic
